Description: A circular stamp probably for decorating the centre of large Egyptian Red Slip A pottery bowls and plates, now broken and half lost. It has a tall conical grip at the centre back, pierced from side to side. The pattern is incuse: within a circle is a pentagram star with a small circle at the centre. In the two surviving areas between the arms of the star are an oval device and an L-shaped one, possibly omicron and lambda. The pattern was probably carved out of the leather-hard clay. Pink Aswan clay.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: John Gadsby, a mid-nineteenth-century traveller in Egypt. Acquired at Elephantine. Late Roman, about AD 500-600.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3599)
